docs.lead_paragraph: At first, it seemed that it might be a statistical blip. But no, public health officials said today, it is a definite and striking trend: Massachusetts, they believe, has become the first state where more babies are born to women over the age of 30 than under it. State figures made public this week showed that among Massachusetts women who gave birth in 1998, about 43,000 were 30 or over, and about 39,000 were under 30. That contrasted sharply with state figures as recent as those from 1990, when only about 37,000 women 30 and over gave birth, compared with 55,000 under 30. In 1980, the number of new mothers under 30 was nearly triple the new mothers 30 and over.

headline.main: Massachusetts Is Set Apart In Ratio of Older Mothers

docs.abstract: Massachusetts public health officials say statistics suggest state may be first in which more babies are born to women over age of 30 than under it; statistics show among women who gave birth in 1998, about 43,000 were 30 or over, and that about 39,000 were under 30; in 1990, only 37,000 women 30 years or older gave birth, compared with 55,000 under 30; in 1980, number of new mothers under 30 was nearly triple new mothers 30 and over; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lorraine Lacaillade, a 75-year-old widow in Bolton, about 25 miles southeast of here, lives on about $12,000 a year, most of it from Social Security. She takes prescription drugs for arthritis and other conditions that would cost more than $1,000 a year if she had to pay for them herself. But this is Vermont, a state in the vanguard of offering health benefits to its residents. Under the Vermont Health Access Plan, a program for people who are earning just enough to make ends meet, Mrs. Lacaillade only pays $3 a month for her medicine.

headline.main: Expansion of Medical Benefits Puts Vermont in the Vanguard

docs.abstract: Vermont is in vanguard in offering health benefits to residents, with benefits unmatched elsewhere in US; 93.5 percent of all residents have health insurance, including essentially all children; array of health benefits offered by state discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A pact was adopted by the International Labor Organization to upgrade a 1952 treaty that strengthens the rights of women workers. The agreement extends maternity leave from 12 to 14 weeks, guarantees women the right to the same jobs after their leaves, bars pregnancy tests for job applicants and strengthens provisions for breast feeding. Elizabeth Olson
